Question: 'what is the marks distribution of the exams?'
Informational: For theory subjects, the semester-end examination carries 70 marks and internal assessment carries 30 marks, which includes a written test of 20 marks, attendance of 5 marks, and behavioural conduct of 5 marks. For practical subjects, the semester-end practical examination carries 70 marks and internal assessment carries 30 marks, which includes internal practical of 20 marks, viva-voce of 5 marks, and practical file of 5 marks. The grading system follows CBCS with letter grades and grade points on a 10-point scale. For more information, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx
Guidance oriented: In theory subjects, students are evaluated through a 70-mark semester-end examination and a 30-mark internal assessment consisting of a written test (20 marks), attendance (5 marks), and behavioural conduct (5 marks). For practical subjects, evaluation includes a 70-mark semester-end practical examination and a 30-mark internal assessment comprising internal practical (20 marks), viva-voce (5 marks), and practical file (5 marks). The college follows the CBCS grading system with letter grades and grade points based on a 10-point scale. For more information, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx
Institutional: The evaluation scheme for theory subjects includes a semester-end examination of 70 marks and an internal assessment of 30 marks, comprising a written test (20 marks), attendance (5 marks), and behavioural conduct (5 marks). For practical subjects, assessment consists of a semester-end practical examination of 70 marks and an internal assessment of 30 marks, including internal practical (20 marks), viva-voce (5 marks), and practical file (5 marks). Grading is conducted under the CBCS system using letter grades and grade points on a 10-point scale. For more information, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx
Conversational: For theory subjects, you’ll have a 70-mark semester-end exam and 30 marks for internal assessment, which includes a written test, attendance, and behavioural conduct. Practical subjects also have a 70-mark semester-end practical exam and 30 marks for internal assessment, covering internal practicals, viva-voce, and the practical file. The college follows the CBCS grading system with letter grades on a 10-point scale. For more information, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx

When are internal assessments conducted?'
Informational: Internal tests are conducted twice in a semester before the final external examinations. Each test usually covers two units and is conducted for 20 marks. For more information on exams and assessments, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx
Guidance oriented: The college conducts two internal tests in each semester before the final external exams. Each internal test generally includes two units and is evaluated for 20 marks. For more information on exams and assessments, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx
Institutional: Internal tests are conducted twice during each semester prior to the final external examinations. Each test typically covers two units and carries a total of 20 marks. For more information on exams and assessments, visit https://www.npgc.in/Academics-ExamAssesCBCS.aspx

Question: does medical leave counts in attendance?'
Informational: Students with attendance below the mandatory 75% are required to submit an application along with a medical certificate.
Guidance oriented: If your attendance is less than the mandatory 75%, you must submit an application and provide a medical certificate to the college
Institutional: Students whose attendance falls below the prescribed 75% are expected to submit an application accompanied by a medical certificate for consideration.
Conversational: If your attendance is under 75%, you need to submit an application and a medical certificate to explain your absence.

Question: 'What happens in case of attendance shortage?'
Informational: Students must submit an application along with a medical certificate if their attendance is below the mandatory 75%. If a medical certificate is not provided, an additional fee may be charged, the admit card issuance may be delayed or restricted, and the student may not be permitted to fill out the scholarship form.
Guidance oriented: If your attendance is below the required 75%, you are required to submit an application and a medical certificate. In case the medical certificate is not submitted, you may be charged an additional fee, your admit card issuance could be delayed or affected, and you may not be allowed to apply for a scholarship.
Institutional: Students whose attendance falls below the mandatory requirement of 75% are required to submit an application along with a valid medical certificate. Failure to submit the medical certificate may result in the imposition of an additional fee, delay or restriction in the issuance of the admit card, and ineligibility to fill the scholarship form.
Conversational: If your attendance is under 75%, you’ll need to submit an application along with a medical certificate. If the medical certificate is not submitted, you might have to pay an extra fee, your admit card could be delayed or held up, and you may not be able to fill out the scholarship form.

Question: 'how can I check my attendance?'
Informational: Students’ attendance records are maintained in a register. Students may ask the teacher for their attendance percentage for a specific subject. The attendance percentage is calculated at the end of each month.
Guidance oriented: Attendance for each subject is recorded in a register. If you want to know your attendance percentage, you can request it from the concerned teacher. Attendance percentages are calculated at the end of every month.
Institutional: Student attendance is recorded in an official register. Students may approach the respective teacher to obtain their attendance percentage for a particular subject. Attendance percentages are computed at the end of each month.
Conversational: Your attendance is recorded in a register for each subject. You can ask your teacher for your attendance percentage anytime, and the percentage is calculated at the end of every month.

Question: 'what documents are required for admission?'
Informational: Applicants are required to attach self-attested copies of the following documents with their application: Pass Certificate and Marksheet of Class X (10th), Pass Certificate and Marksheet of Class XII (12th), Marksheet of the last examination passed, proof of not taking admission elsewhere along with a notarized declaration of no legal issues (if the qualifying examination was passed in the specified earlier years), Character Certificate from the Head of the last institution attended (original to be submitted at the time of counseling), Character Certificate from the Superintendent of Police, District Magistrate, or Gazetted Officer for private candidates (certified after the specified date), and an attested copy of the Caste Certificate or CMO Certificate for reserved category applicants (original to be produced during counseling). For more information on admission procedure, visit https://www.npgc.in/Admission-Procedures.aspx
Guidance oriented: While submitting the application, applicants should ensure that self-attested copies of all required documents are attached. These include Class X and Class XII pass certificates and marksheets, the marksheet of the last examination passed, and, where applicable, proof of not taking admission elsewhere along with a notarized declaration regarding no legal issues. A Character Certificate from the Head of the last institution attended is required, with the original to be submitted during counseling. Private candidates must provide a Character Certificate issued by the Superintendent of Police, District Magistrate, or a Gazetted Officer after the specified date. Applicants applying under a reserved category must also attach an attested copy of the relevant Caste or CMO Certificate, with the original to be shown at counseling. For more information on admission procedure, visit https://www.npgc.in/Admission-Procedures.aspx
Institutional: All applicants must submit self-attested copies of the prescribed documents along with their application. These documents include the Pass Certificate and Marksheet of Class X (10th), Pass Certificate and Marksheet of Class XII (12th), and the Marksheet of the last examination passed. Candidates who passed the qualifying examination in the specified earlier years must additionally submit proof of not having taken admission elsewhere along with a notarized declaration stating that there are no legal issues. A Character Certificate issued by the Head of the last institution attended is mandatory, with the original to be produced at the time of counseling. Private candidates are required to submit a Character Certificate issued by the Superintendent of Police, District Magistrate, or a Gazetted Officer, certified after the specified date. Reserved category candidates must submit an attested copy of the applicable Caste Certificate or CMO Certificate, with the original to be verified during counseling. For more information on admission procedure, visit https://www.npgc.in/Admission-Procedures.aspx
Conversational: When applying, make sure to attach self-attested copies of all required documents. This includes your Class 10 and Class 12 pass certificates and marksheets, as well as the marksheet of the last exam you passed. If you completed your qualifying exam in the specified earlier years, you’ll also need to submit proof that you didn’t take admission elsewhere along with a notarized declaration stating there are no legal issues. A Character Certificate from the Head of your last institution is required, and you’ll need to submit the original during counseling. Private candidates must provide a Character Certificate issued by the Superintendent of Police, District Magistrate, or a Gazetted Officer after the specified date. If you are applying under a reserved category, don’t forget to attach an attested copy of your Caste or CMO Certificate and bring the original for counseling. For more information on admission procedure, visit https://www.npgc.in/Admission-Procedures.aspx

Question: Does npgc have study centers for distance learning?'
Informational: National Post Graduate College (NPGC) has a Distance Learning Centre that serves as a study centre for IGNOU (Indira Gandhi National Open University) and Uttar Pradesh Rajarshi Tandon Open University (UPRTOU). These centres provide certificate, diploma, and degree programs in distance mode, along with regular consultation classes and remedial sessions. NPGC does not offer its own distance learning or online programs independently; it functions solely as a support centre for IGNOU and UPRTOU students.
Guidance oriented: NPGC has a Distance Learning Centre that acts as a study centre for IGNOU and UPRTOU. If you are enrolled in distance programs through these universities, you can attend consultation classes, remedial sessions, and access support at NPGC. Please note that NPGC does not run its own distance learning or online programs—it only provides assistance to students of IGNOU and UPRTOU.
Institutional: National Post Graduate College (NPGC) maintains a Distance Learning Centre functioning as a study centre for IGNOU (Indira Gandhi National Open University) and Uttar Pradesh Rajarshi Tandon Open University (UPRTOU). These centres facilitate certificate, diploma, and degree programs in distance mode and organize consultation classes and remedial sessions for enrolled students. NPGC does not independently offer distance learning degrees or online programs; it provides support services for distance learners affiliated with IGNOU and UPRTOU.
Conversational: NPGC has a Distance Learning Centre where students of IGNOU and UPRTOU can get support. The centre runs certificate, diploma, and degree programs in distance mode and holds consultation classes and remedial sessions. Just so you know, NPGC doesn’t offer its own online or distance programs—it’s mainly a support hub for students from these open universities.

Question: How do I apply for scholarship?'
What is the eligibility for scholarship?'
Informational: UP Scholarship eligibility requires the applicant to be a permanent resident of Uttar Pradesh and enrolled in an institution registered on the UP Scholarship portal. Income limits are as follows: OBC – less than ₹2,00,000; General/Minority/SC/ST – less than ₹2,50,000. For Post-Matric scholarships, applicants are generally required to have passed the previous year’s examination. A valid UP domicile certificate, caste certificate, Rashan card or other state-issued proof of residence is typically required for verification before disbursal. Note: Scholarship notice is always shared by the department head  which includes application due date and eligibility criteria.
Guidance oriented: To apply for the UP Scholarship, make sure you are a permanent resident of Uttar Pradesh and studying at an institution listed on the UP Scholarship portal. Check that your family income meets the limits: OBC – below ₹2,00,000; General/Minority/SC/ST – below ₹2,50,000. If you are applying for a Post-Matric scholarship, ensure you have passed the previous year’s exam. Keep your UP domicile or caste certificate handy, as officials may require it for verification before funds are disbursed. Note: Scholarship notice is always shared by the department head  which includes application due date and eligibility criteria.
Institutional: Eligibility for the UP Scholarship is limited to students who are permanent residents of Uttar Pradesh and enrolled in institutions registered on the UP Scholarship portal. Income criteria are as follows: OBC – less than ₹2,00,000; General, Minority, SC, ST – less than ₹2,50,000. For Post-Matric scholarships, applicants are generally expected to have successfully completed the preceding academic year. A valid UP domicile certificate, caste certificate, or other state-issued proof of residence is required for verification prior to the disbursal of scholarship funds. Note: Scholarship notice is always shared by the department head  which includes application due date and eligibility criteria.
Conversational: To be eligible for the UP Scholarship, you need to be a permanent resident of Uttar Pradesh and study at a college registered on the UP Scholarship portal. Your family income should be below ₹2,00,000 if you’re OBC, and below ₹2,50,000 if you’re General, Minority, SC, or ST. For Post-Matric scholarships, you usually need to have passed last year’s exam. Also, make sure you have a UP domicile certificate or caste certificate ready, as it’s often checked before the scholarship money is released. Note: Scholarship notice is always shared by the department head  which includes application due date and eligibility criteria.

Question: How much money is credited in scholarship?'
Informational: The UP scholarship amount is calculated based on the course pursued, the student’s category (SC/ST/OBC/Minority/General), family annual income, type of institution (government or private), and the tuition fees and eligible allowances for the course.
Guidance oriented: Your UP scholarship amount depends on several factors: the course you are pursuing, your category (SC/ST/OBC/Minority/General), your family’s annual income, whether you study in a government or private institution, and the tuition fees and eligible allowances for your course.
Institutional: The calculation of the UP scholarship amount takes into account the course, the student’s category (SC/ST/OBC/Minority/General), family annual income, type of institution (government or private), and the tuition fees along with any eligible allowances for the respective course.
Conversational: The amount you get from the UP scholarship depends on a few things: what course you are pursuing, your category (SC/ST/OBC/Minority/General), your family’s yearly income, whether your college is government or private, and the tuition fees plus any allowances for your course.

Question: ls scholarship different for SC/ST/OBC/General?'
Informational: No, the UP scholarship form is the same for all social categories; however, the disbursement amount varies for each social group
Guidance oriented: The scholarship form is the same for every social category, but the amount you receive will differ depending on your social group.
Institutional: The UP scholarship application form is uniform across all social categories; however, the scholarship disbursement amount is determined according to the applicant’s social group.
Conversational: You use the same form no matter your social category, but the scholarship amount you get will be different for each group.

Question: When do we get scholarship amount?'
Informational: The scholarship amount starts to be disbursed after one or two months of application submission. You can check your UP Scholarship status at https://scholarship.up.gov.in
Guidance oriented: After submitting your application, the scholarship amount is usually disbursed within one to two months. Applicants are advised to check their UP Scholarship status on https://scholarship.up.gov.in
Institutional: It is informed that the scholarship amount is disbursed approximately one to two months after the submission of the application. Students may check their UP Scholarship status through the official website: https://scholarship.up.gov.in
Conversational: Once you submit your application, the scholarship amount usually comes in a month or two. You can keep track of your UP Scholarship status at https://scholarship.up.gov.in

how can i borrow books from library?'
Informational: You can borrow books from the library by using a library card. A student can issue up to 6 books per semester. The book code must be entered on the library card and signed by the librarian.
Guidance oriented: To borrow books from the library, students need to have a valid library card. Each student is allowed to issue up to 6 books per semester. Ensure that the book code is recorded on your library card and signed by the librarian.
Institutional: Students are informed that books may be issued from the library only upon presentation of a valid library card. A student may issue up to 6 books per semester. The book code must be duly entered on the library card and authenticated by the librarian’s signature.
Conversational: Borrowing books is easy! Just make sure you have your library card. You can issue up to 6 books per semester—don’t forget to write the book code on your card and get it signed by the librarian.

Question: what is alumni cell ?

Conversational: The NPGC Alumni Cell keeps alumni connected to the college through networking, events, and mentorship. The cell is a great way for former students, current students, and the college to stay in touch!

Does the college publish any journal?'
Informational: The NPGC Intellectus is an international, multidisciplinary, peer-reviewed journal focusing on technological, organizational, and social domains. The journal publishes research addressing relevant problems in the planning, analysis, design, implementation, exploration, and management of information systems. It includes original research papers from Science and Technology, Arts and Humanities, and Commerce and Management. For more information regarding previous publications, guidelines for submission or contact information, students can visit: https://npgcij.com or  If any query regarding publication, contact on +91 7905035668.
Guidance oriented: NPGC Intellectus is an international, multidisciplinary, peer-reviewed journal that focuses on technological, organizational, and social domains. It publishes research related to planning, analysis, design, implementation, exploration, and management of information systems. The journal accepts original research papers from Science and Technology, Arts and Humanities, and Commerce and Management. For more information regarding previous publications, guidelines for submission or contact information, students can visit: https://npgcij.com or  If any query regarding publication, contact on +91 7905035668.
Institutional: NPGC Intellectus is an international, multidisciplinary, peer-reviewed journal with a focus on technological, organizational, and social domains. The journal publishes original research addressing key issues in the planning, analysis, design, implementation, exploration, and management of information systems. Contributions are accepted from the fields of Science and Technology, Arts and Humanities, and Commerce and Management. For more information regarding previous publications, guidelines for submission or contact information, students can visit: https://npgcij.com or  If any query regarding publication, contact on +91 7905035668.
Conversational: The NPGC Intellectus is an international, multidisciplinary, peer-reviewed journal that covers technological, organizational, and social areas. It publishes research that looks at real-world problems in planning, analysis, design, implementation, exploration, and management of information systems, and includes original research papers from Science and Technology, Arts and Humanities, and Commerce and Management.For more information regarding previous publications, guidelines for submission or contact information, students can visit: https://npgcij.com or  If any query regarding publication, contact on +91 7905035668.

Does college offers any hostel?'
Informational: The college provides hostel accommodation for students from other cities and states. Separate hostels are available for girls with a capacity of approximately 155 students and for boys with a capacity of approximately 100 students. The hostels are well managed and maintain discipline. Hostel facilities include internet access, air-conditioned rooms, generator sets, water coolers with purifiers, geysers, meditation rooms, a cultural hall, a common reading area, common rooms with televisions (DTH), a gymnasium and yoga center, a badminton court and indoor games, a mess facility, CCTV security, medical facilities, and a furnished guest house for parents of inmates.
Guidance oriented: Students coming from other cities or states can avail hostel accommodation provided by the college. There are separate hostels for girls (around 155 capacity) and boys (around 100 capacity), both of which are well managed and disciplined. The hostels offer facilities such as internet access, air-conditioned rooms, generator sets, water coolers with purifiers, geysers, meditation rooms, a cultural hall, a common reading area, TV common rooms with DTH, a gymnasium and yoga center, a badminton court and indoor games, mess facilities, CCTV security, medical support, and a furnished guest house for parents of inmates.
Institutional: The college offers hostel accommodation to students from other cities and states. Separate hostels are available for girls with an approximate capacity of 155 students and for boys with an approximate capacity of 100 students. The hostels are well managed and operate with discipline. Hostel amenities include internet connectivity, air-conditioned rooms, generator backup, water coolers with purifiers, geysers, meditation rooms, a cultural hall, common reading areas, common rooms equipped with DTH television, a gymnasium and yoga center, badminton courts and indoor games, mess facilities, CCTV surveillance, medical facilities, and a furnished guest house for parents of inmates.
Conversational: Yes, the college provides hostel facilities for students from other cities and states. There are separate hostels for girls (around 155 capacity) and boys (around 100 capacity), and they’re known to be well managed and disciplined. The hostels come with lots of facilities like internet access, air-conditioned rooms, power backup, water coolers with purifiers, geysers, meditation rooms, a cultural hall, common reading spaces, TV common rooms with DTH, a gym and yoga center, badminton and indoor games, mess facilities, CCTV security, medical support, and even a furnished guest house for parents of inmates.

Question: 'Are there any students clubs?'
Informational:
NCC (National Cadet Corps) – A voluntary service-oriented cadet program providing discipline, military training, and opportunities to participate in camps and events.
NSS (National Service Scheme) – A social service unit focusing on community engagement, outreach activities, cleanliness drives, health awareness, environmental programs, and more.
Rovers & Rangers Club (Scouts & Guides) – A club promoting service, discipline, leadership, and various outdoor and community activities.
C.B. Gupta Literary & Cultural Club – A club dedicated to promoting literary and cultural interests among students.
Sports & Games Club – Organises sports events, competitions, and physical-education-related activities.
The college also has committees such as the Students’ Welfare Committee, Committee for Cultural Activities, Library Committee, and Magazine Committee, where students can take active roles and contribute to campus life.
Guidance oriented:
Students can get involved in several clubs and committees at the college:
NCC (National Cadet Corps) – Join for discipline, military training, and participation in camps and events.
NSS (National Service Scheme) – Engage in community service, cleanliness drives, health awareness, and environmental programs.
Rovers & Rangers Club – Develop leadership and discipline while participating in outdoor and community activities.
C.B. Gupta Literary & Cultural Club – Explore literary and cultural interests.
Sports & Games Club – Take part in sports events, competitions, and physical education activities.
Students can also actively contribute through committees such as the Students’ Welfare Committee, Committee for Cultural Activities, Library Committee, and Magazine Committee.
Institutional:
The college offers multiple clubs and committees for student participation:
NCC (National Cadet Corps) – A voluntary, service-oriented cadet program providing discipline, military training, and opportunities for participation in camps and events.
NSS (National Service Scheme) – A social service unit focusing on community engagement, outreach, cleanliness drives, health awareness, environmental programs, and related activities.
Rovers & Rangers Club (Scouts & Guides) – A club promoting service, discipline, leadership, and outdoor and community activities.
C.B. Gupta Literary & Cultural Club – A club dedicated to fostering literary and cultural interests among students.
Sports & Games Club – Organises sports events, competitions, and physical education activities.
In addition, the college maintains committees such as the Students’ Welfare Committee, Committee for Cultural Activities, Library Committee, and Magazine Committee, providing avenues for active student participation in campus life.
Conversational:
There are plenty of clubs and committees you can join at college:
NCC (National Cadet Corps) – Great for learning discipline, military training, and joining camps and events.
NSS (National Service Scheme) – Get involved in community service, cleanliness drives, health programs, and environmental activities.
Rovers & Rangers Club – Build leadership skills and have fun with outdoor and community activities.
C.B. Gupta Literary & Cultural Club – Perfect for students who love literature and culture.
Sports & Games Club – Take part in sports events, competitions, and physical activities.
Plus, you can actively contribute through committees like the Students’ Welfare Committee, Committee for Cultural Activities, Library Committee, and Magazine Committee, helping make campus life more vibrant.

Is there any college magazine?
Informational:
NPGC publishes its own magazines and periodicals:

Abhivyakti – Annual college magazine featuring poems, stories, articles, news items, photographs, and achievements, with contributions from students and faculty.

In‑Sight – Monthly magazine focused on campus events and announcements, also accepting contributions relevant to student activities.
Additional publications include e-newsletters and other scholarly or departmental releases, such as monographs, research papers, leaflets, pamphlets, and souvenirs for special occasions.
Guidance oriented: NPGC produces several publications for students and faculty. The Abhivyakti is an annual college magazine with poems, stories, articles, news items, photographs, and achievements contributed by both students and faculty. The In‑Sight is a monthly magazine highlighting campus events and announcements, and it also welcomes contributions related to student activities. The college also publishes e-newsletters and other scholarly or departmental materials, including monographs, research papers, leaflets, pamphlets, and souvenirs for special occasions.
Institutional:
NPGC publishes official magazines and periodicals, including:

Abhivyakti – An annual college magazine comprising poems, stories, articles, news items, photographs, and achievements, with contributions from students and faculty.

In‑Sight – A monthly magazine dedicated to campus events and announcements, which also accepts submissions relevant to student activities.
Additional publications encompass e-newsletters and other scholarly or departmental releases, such as monographs, research papers, leaflets, pamphlets, and souvenirs for special occasions.
Conversational: NPGC has its own magazines and periodicals. Abhivyakti is the annual college magazine, full of poems, stories, articles, news, photos, and achievements from both students and faculty. In‑Sight is a monthly magazine about campus events and announcements, and it’s happy to include contributions related to student activities. The college also puts out e-newsletters and other materials like monographs, research papers, leaflets, pamphlets, and souvenirs for special occasions.
